story:
Thanks for being part of one of our biggest projects!
This campaign is sponsored and organized by

EASY NAVIGATION

What We're Doing / Why / Community Benefits / Risks & Challenges

Other Ways to Help / Perks / Stretch Goals / Achievements / FAQ / About Us

Featured Brands & Affiliated Partners / Disclaimer / Terms of Idea Submission

People Are Talking

What We're Doing

(Where your money and our money is going)

A Brand New Entertainment and Personal Development Facility
(Part 1 of our campaign is to fund the development of an indoor skatepark)

*Please note: We aren't 'Re-building' the Skatepark of Memphis that once existed.
This is an entirely new project and we've been granted permission from previous owners to use the original name. Skatepark of Memphis was built with years of hard work, dedication and community support. We do not wish to discredit the family that spent their time and money to birth such a great experience for the Memphis alternative sports community, Memphis' independent music scene and the youth who contributed to the success of the park and it's name. We have a unique opportunity to make Memphis a part of the, now, mainstream sport.

The provision of a sport or recreation facility can significantly enhance the quality of life. Activities held within sport and recreation facilities can encourage participation, promote health and well-being and foster a sense of community. However, planning a sport or recreation facility is an involved and sometimes difficult task. Our project is big. OUR PROJECT IS HUGE and considering that this is an individual effort to support independent artists, designers, business owners, brands and, in general, creatives, The project may or may not be partially funded by the city/state and could take 1-3 years to be fully funded before construction begins. The park will be designed and constructed by California Skateparks.
The photos below are rendered to represent quality and do NOT accurately represent architecture, park design, material use or scale.

In addition, our goal is to open a skate-bike-inline shop (featuring products from both local and well known brands) and a flagship popup shop featuring only products from sponsored artists, affiliate partners & Memphis-based Indie apparel brands The Label Lust Apparel + Affiliated Partners like ME Skateboarding Co.
The photos below are rendered to represent quality and minimalist taste but do NOT accurately represent architecture, shop design, material use or scale.

The Skatepark of Memphis will be a privately owned park. In an effort to support local independent talent, local small and big independently owned businesses, provide job and internship opportunities, education, relationship and wealth building strategies to the Memphis community, the Indoor skatepark and surrounding facilities (eg. apparel design, recording, photography, videography, visual art, technology, dance, business network and digital branding studios) will be accessible via monthly/annual memberships or pay-per-day and pay-per-session rates. This would allow us to keep the park open forever and could allow us to keep the lights on 24/7. The facility will be constructed with state-of-the art materials and technology and the park itself would be constructed with concrete, minimizing hazards and upkeep costs.

Back to top.

A Professionally Designed Concrete Skatepark Will:

• Provide a safe challenging place for skateboarding (and similar extreme sports), allowing participants to develop as athletes
• Provide an alternative to team sports, to develop motor skills & balance in youth and the young-at-heart. Playgrounds are provided for younger children, but for older youth who don’t participate in team sports, there is often nothing.
• Attract visitors (skatepark enthusiasts & spectators) who enjoy skateboarding & similar extreme sports. When people visit they spend money!
• Make community more youth-friendly & give youth the message that they’re accepted & valued members of the community, by giving them a place to call their own & a creative outlet to express themselves
• Provide opportunity for healthy activity for youth, helping curb problems of inactivity & drug abuse (According to local Addiction Services, the most common reason given by youth for drug abuse is boredom.)
• Provide opportunities to host events, shows & jams (competitions), presenting skating in a format that people can understand & appreciate. Skateboarding is a great spectator sport!
• Provide opportunities for “hard to reach, non-joining youth” to get involved in the community & foster creativity as each skater develops his own personal style and skills

According to veteran skateboarder Dan Hughes, “Skateboarding reaches these “at risk” youth, like no other sport. And it’s cool too. But, people are out of touch with what is happening, and just want to get these annoying skateboarders out of their hair. All the while, kids are learning that as skaters they are second-class citizens. Yet, it’s these same skateboarders who are learning a valuable work ethic. Because, believe me, if you don’t work hard and commit to a trick, you won’t land it. They also learn how to work independently, how to be creative, and develop their own style.”

• Provide social opportunities by bringing different ages and social groups together, encouraging interaction and appreciation of each other; bring families together who enjoy skating as a family
• Empower youth by involving them fully in the process of establishing the park, enabling them to work with community elders, learning how government works & how they can become more active citizens
• Encourage youth to interact independently & develop socially, learning how to take turns & help each other learn new tricks
• Mitigate street skating problems, protecting private & public property from damage & reducing police time required to follow up on complaints. For example, 75% of 24 communities surveyed by the City of Calgary in 1998, after their skatepark opened, reported a significant reduction in the skate problem.
• Reduce pressure on hospitals as a result of reduced injuries from skating on rough surfaces and in traffic areas, i.e. street-skating. (According to Health Canada, only 5% of skateboarding injuries take place in skateparks.)
• Provide a healthy release for pent-up aggression & frustration
• Teach the importance of a positive attitude & belief in oneself. To progress in skateboarding, one must trust oneself & believe that they can do it!
• Provide economic benefits.

“Community Access to a variety of recreational opportunities encourages business investment from outside the community, acts as a driver for immigration, and encourages resident retention (particularly among youth). Destination marketing and tourism development are closely tied with the number and quality of recreation activities developed and available.”

A skatepark would fit well into Memphis Grizzlies' established slogan “Grit n Grind”
-Grit defining Courage and Resolve; Strength of Character
-Grind defining Work-ethic and Persistence; Mental and Physical Dedication to setting and completing Goals and literally grinding (obviously)

Skateboarding is HUGE, just not hugely supported in Memphis.

Thanks to Jim Barnum of Spectrum Skateparks and California Skateparks for many of the above ideas.

photo source: dewtour.com
Back to top.

How will this benefit the Memphis Youth?

The myth surrounding skateparks is that they are a breeding ground for crime and other illicit activities. While there will be an occasional "bad seed", providing designated spaces for positive activities is the best way to curb unlawful behavior among youth. When the youth has nothing to do or nowhere to go - that is when they are more likely to cause trouble and risk not only other people's lives, but their own.

It's no secret that children who are involved in team sports don't have the time to get into trouble, but it turns out you don't have to drag them to the soccer field or baseball diamond. Activities you may not expect - like skateboarding - might be just what teens and adolescents need. Research out of the University of North Carolina found that skateboarding is among the activities that might help keep children out of trouble. Many adults who aren't involved in the skateboarding community see the group of boarders as being a little more on the risky side, but instead of being on the risky side, they are actually protected from those behaviors.

Source: NBC Philadelphia
"Keeping Active is the Best way to keep kids out of trouble" April 3, 2006

By all means, skateboarding can be a dangerous sport. It's indubitably dangerous when skating in the streets due to a lack in public skating parks, but what I believe is more dangerous than that are public parks that are open 24/7 with no lighting, weatherproofing, enforced regulations or supervision.
An indoor, well-maintained, well-supervised, well-lit, well-ventilated and regulated skating facility would revoke illegal activity, destruction of public & private property, violence, and unethical influence and allow skaters an opportunity to leave their homes and be active on days of bad weather; the healthy alternative to playing video games and watching Netflix.

One of the psycho-social benefits is to feel safe again. Reclaiming public spaces helps people feel like a community and the busier the place, the more appealing for the youth and the safer people feel.

The majority of skateboarding injuries happen outside of skateparks. The most common injuries are falls due to surface irregularities and collisions with motor vehicles or pedestrians. Skateboarding is going to happen whether skateparks exist or not, so the best way to keep youth safe is to provide to them access to positively influenced, safe, designated spaces to pursue their activity.


Back to top.

In Association with Skatepark of Memphis


AWARE TO CARE Greater Memphis Area Protection Program
(To donate protective recreation gear)
SPOM SHOP's Game of S.K.E.I.G.H.T Live Broadcast 2017 in Memphis TN
(Competitive event to increase community and Corporate involvement)
Skatepark of Memphis Aggressive Inline, & BMX Skateshop Best Trick 2017
(Competitive event to increase community and Corporate involvement)
SPOM's Skateboarding for Purpose in Memphis Board Donor
(To donate complete skateboards to kids and young adults)
(designs and names subject to change)

Risks & Challenges

There is not a single parks manager who doesn’t see a way to improve any recreational facility. The challenges facing parks are everywhere; the expensive maintenance costs of a new soccer field, finding qualified volunteers for an after-school program, or the lack of  land for an off-leash dog park. The fact is that no recreational facility is without its particular needs and no project is perfect in every way.

Skateparks are a relative newcomer to the Parks & Recreation world and it can be difficult to sort out all of the voices with something to say. Attorneys deliver a list of policies and devices necessary to mitigate liability. Planners have a short list of available sites appropriate for this kind of development (if at all). Meanwhile, the neighborhood delivers its own list of concerns about noise and nuisance. While this is all getting sorted out the skateboarders are recreating in the streets. The business community is fed up with their ledges being ground down to nothing and the police are writing tickets to skaters when they have better things to do. Everyone wants the new skatepark but few people can agree on what and where it should be, work together to volunteer or find the money to donate. This is where skateparks begin to fail.

We’re all familiar with the difficult environment in which skateparks are expected to become successes. It should come as no surprise that sometimes they fail to meet everyone’s expectations. Hope is not lost! There are still options even when it feels like every avenue has been explored.

Our biggest expenses will probably be RENT and INSURANCE. While providing services and products would be a great way to financially support brands & businesses and the communities that support those brands & businesses, we do not expect to cover insurance, rent, utility, employment, management and upkeep fees associated with owning a skatepark from these outlets alone (meaning we have other plans in place to generate income within and outside of the new facility).

We hope to find a SPACE large enough to include a parking lot for plenty of parking space - an indoor park large enough to allow simultaneous use by boarders, inline skaters and bikers safely - and a building large enough to include multiple rooms for retail, creative opportunities for partners/customers/clients/members, the park (of course), shows (that don't interrupt park activity) and large events (like televised board/bike/skate competitions, club parties and fashion shows  -  things that would increase community involvement, consumer spending & drive INCOME to help fund park maintenance, employment, product design & manufacturing, advertising, sponsorships and overheads.
While searching for a place to call home, we have to consider thing like LICENSING, ZONING CLEARANCE and PERMITS (for clubbing, indoor parks, commerce, broadcasting, etc)

Building a concrete park will be EXPENSIVE. The advantage is that maintenance costs will decrease drastically. Buying (not renting) a building will be VERY EXPENSIVE. The advantage, though, is that we (park users) can make the rules and make any decisions necessary for the satisfaction and safety of our community.

DESIGN is commonly an issue. Fortunately, California Skateparks has one of the best reputations in skatepark-building history. Unfortunately, they're not architects. We're still searching for the right architect for the job.

TIME is a major concern. Will the park open this year? Lets be realistic - probably not, considering the goals we've set and are determined to achieve.

SUPPORT - Under-funding a facility that is expected to meet the needs for the entire local community AND attract visitors. Skateboarders aren't millionaires. Not even some of the best professionals. Mid-level skaters earn $50 to $100K a year, while the really good guys make between $500K and $1 million. But how much of that do they have to fund a park? How much of that do they actually keep? But believe it or not, it's rarely about the money. Basically skaters get paid to do what they would be doing anyway, which is trying to skate better than the laws of physics allow." Most amateur skaters don't have enough money in their pockets to replace the skateboard they just broke and if they do, they've usually already got in mind where they're going to spend it and what they're going to buy. Our funding is likely to come from investors, parents, sponsors and ourselves (with pleasure).

LOW CAPACITY - Underestimating the value of (and not planning for) the skatepark as a social space to the local youth. Seating and other aspects of design that make the space comfortable and inviting are very important to the long-term health of the park. If the facility is designed to handle this social function it will be that much better off. When the popularity of the new skatepark is underestimated, particularly when site amenities and the surroundings are not designed to be social spaces, behavior at the park can become unruly.

OPPORTUNITY - Embarking upon the process of creating a new skatepark is a great opportunity to embrace a popular and fascinating youth activity. The new park should be seen as a boon to the community that will be VERY popular with the youth. With proper planning and good decisions, the skatepark will be a landmark for the entire community. This is a rare and exciting opportunity.

We have three two options:

1.) Find a location and building (usually a warehouse space) big enough to include a spacious parking lot, seating (for shows, competitions and jams) and floor space (for broadcasters and film gear during events), and a skatepark big enough to include efficient design for: sectioning (to give bikers, boarders and inline skaters access to a particular section during a 30 minute session if needed), skill level (to give young children or beginners a safe section to practice and progress) and ride-ability (to ensure the entire park can be utilized and enjoyed at it's utmost potential for each rider's style and preference).

2.) Find an empty lot for reasons mentioned above and build a brand new facility. (preferred over renovating or experiencing design limitations with existing lots)

(We think we've found the perfect spot downtown near the Pyramid where we can drive visitor traffic and increase sales for nearby businesses, but we're still doing research on zoning and permits. If you've got information that may beneficial to us, please email support@theskateparkofmemphis.com)

3.) Build a free, outdoor skatepark Memphis already has a few of these and they are GREAT! If we decided to raise money to build a free outdoor park we, instead, would invest that money into improving the existing parks to make them safer, more enjoyable, well lit and more complete. For example:

-We would add a pool (or pools, and we don't mean a swimming pool), dedicated lighting and more seating with outdoor heaters to the Houston High park

- Expand and add concrete sections and lighting to Southaven Skate Park

- Add lighting to Tobey park

- And of course we'd do whatever we can for the DIY guys over at ALTOWN.

Often, Memphis' ridiculous weather and lack of necessary resources and space make it hard for kids, young adults and long-time riders to fully enjoy skateboarding outdoors. We don't want to discourage support for local parks, instead we'd love to give Memphis skaters, bikers and visitors from all over the world the opportunity to enjoy a full day's worth of skateboarding and have access to a clean, ventilated and safe community-driven environment. These existing parks are VERY important to the Memphis skateboarding community and if when the opportunities unfold, our investments into these parks and their supporting communities are guaranteed.

Back to top.

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you can't contribute a donation, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Ask at least 10 family members and 20 friends to get the word out and make some noise about our YOUR campaign. YES, this is your campaign, right? I'm not going to be in this awesome park all by myself!!
  • We have ideas - execution - shared interest. All we need now is your support.
  • Please use the tools on this page to share our page all over social media, forums and talk to those business owners, principals and salty neighbors who are fed up with your sweet pop, bad-ass attitude and your GRIT & GRIND! We're sure they would LOVE to have you out of their hair!

Do you have questions, comments or requests? Do you offer a service or product that would be beneficial to this project? Where's our video? We're working on a campaign video. Would you like to submit footage to be included in the video? Please mail questions and send links to (1) specific video to
support@theskateparkofmemphis.com

CLAIMED YOUR PERK?
Here's some cool stuff you could win!

(these will be available as perks once we reach some of our goals!)






Back to top.

Quick Answers to FAQs & Replys to Concerns

Q: Will you let bikes in? That would be amazing.
R: Our plan is to have a park both safe and enough for inline, skate and bmx.

C: Looks shady. Who asks for public donations to fund a private business?
R: We do. Reason being, the original SPOM closed down for a few reasons
1. The owners of the wooden park were renting a property.
2. After 7 years, the owners of that property decided to sell the property.
3. A MGMT company took over the property and required the park to back-pay five years of unpaid maintenance fees although the previous property owner had made an agreement with the park owners that they didn't have to pay those fees.
4. By law, the park was forced to pay $30,000 or shut down.
5. The owners had a shop at the park, but a shop definitely does not bring enough income alone to fund the rent and maintenance of a wooden park.
5. Because the money wasn't there, the EPIC Memphis Era had to come to an end.

Q: Why should I fund a private park?
A: If we don't own the park, we don't make the rules. Profits made (if any) would be invested back into improvement of the park, additions to the park, alterations, fund street league-style events, grow the skateboarding community and professional athlete involvement therefore giving local skaters an opportunity to grow in the sport, and give Memphis' youthful skating community a place to go and grow.

C: There isn't enough demand to support an indoor skatepark in Memphis, or else there would already be one...
R: Do you mean "There isn't enough demand" or do you meant "There isn't enough support"? It's all about perspective. With over 300 impressions 1 day into the campaign, I think this is something people have been wanting for a while. There just aren't enough people out there with a GO-GETTER attitude trying to make something happen for the benefit of others. Memphis' support system for independent talents, small businesses, relationships, self-improvement, success, the youth....(I could go on and on)... has kind-of gone to shit. Our community doesn't really feel inspired to do anything unless they know they'll see results tomorrow - unless they know it's going to benefit them in some kind of way - unless it tears down their competition.
See, I'm not about competition, or tearing people down. I'm not about doing everything for the benefit of myself and having that 9-5 job barely making enough to feed my snake (who only needs to eat once a month) and skating at free parks or in the cove every time I want to get on a board, because every time I've I wanted to go out and get on board, the weather said NO. The neighbors complained. The park was dirty. No one being at the public park and the sun nearly generating a cup-full of sweat and the built-up dirt at the bottom of the banks -- weren't worth my almost empty tank of gas. Any request to change or fix an issue at a public park (cracks or a broken rail) or add, lets say, a bowl to the Houston High park is either denied or takes 15 years to finally be fulfilled. If we owned that park it would have been done either by us or with volunteer help of the people who truly wanted it. But because we don't own that park, we have to ask non-skateboarding politicians to do something that would benefit us, but they would have to pay for.

Q: Why is there so much to read?

A: Well, because there's so much to do and we don't have a campaign video (yet)
We're waiting on video submissions from Memphis skaters to land in our inbox and those (usually) take a while to make. The organizers (myself and one other) are pretty busy researching, networking and spending hard-earned money trying to make this thing happen for you. You wouldn't have come this far down the page if you weren't remotely interested. Besides, reading is good practice for the mind and I encourage you to do so more often. A book I recommend reading is Mental Dynamics by K. Thomas Finley.

Q: When will I receive my perk?

A: Receiving your perk(s) often takes time! Selecting a perk as a part of your contribution is not the same thing as buying something online. Perks may require much more than just money to develop, manufacture and distribute. Some perks will be received when our campaign reaches the particular milestone associated with that perk. For example, if you claimed the "You've Got Mail" perk, you'll be the first to know when we find a location - assuming that your address hasn't changed between now and then, you'll receive exclusive 'GRIT & GRIND SPOM' stickers in the mail.

Q: How will I be contacted if I'm the winner of a drawing?

A: Receiving your perk(s) often takes time! Selecting a perk as a part of your contribution is not the same thing as buying something online. Perks may require much more than just money to develop, manufacture and distribute.

Q: Can I claim multiple perks?

A: It's exciting to hear that you've found multiple perks you are interested in claiming! Please note, at this time, we do not have a feature for you to be able to add multiple perks in a single transaction. As such, if you'd like to claim multiple perks, please make a new contribution for each perk.
(Read More about perks here)

Back to top.

About Us

The is an affiliate of The Label Lust Brand & Artist Management Agency. We, are a conglomerate of independent brands which provide 6 service groups to our creative clients and affiliated partner brands:


along with endorsements and sponsorships, essentially eliminating the middle-men and providing countless opportunities for the Memphis community. Our goal as an Agency is to provide to our clients and partners a one-stop-shop of the necessary education, resources and services to enhance their entrepreneur careers and expedite their journey to success.

We hope to redefine what it means to be an independent creative and teach young professionals how to network, collaborate, better understand business, finance and relationship building, and not necessarily what, but where & how to think more efficiently in our more connected, modern world.

Many “Entertainment” companies are more-so interested in making a dollar than providing their clients with the opportunity to do the same. We do not solely consider our customers “Clients”, but instead, Partners. That is what sets our agency apart from our competition. Entering a joint agreement as individual businesses & brands with a common goal to generate residual revenue and marketing exposure for both, or all parties involved, ultimately building wealthier relationships and solid foundations of trust and transparency, all while increasing independent community interest and involvement.

Back to top.

Featured Brands & Affiliate Partners

- CORY OWENS BLOG | Memphis Entrepreneur Club | ME Skateboarding Co. -- Caye Fazer Music | Hope Out Loud Photography | The Label Lust Apparel -- 901 Customs Branding | AUDIOCANVAS STUDIO | 901 King Beatz -- THE SIDEWAYZ Music | No Fake Fans Streetwear | KENNEK Entertainment -- Grit n Grind Streetwear | Venture Streetwear | The Label Lust -- FUNKESKEY Band | VASHNI (The Aquadice) | We Come in Peace Memphis -- DJ 8:00/Memphis as Buck | All Media Digital MGMT | Experience Pints Podcast -

Back to top.

The park would be considered part of The Label Lust Complex (which also may or may not be the final name of the complex. This would be a completely new privately owned park. theskateparkofmemphis.com is in no way associated with the original pre-existing skateparkofmemphis.com but could potentially take it's place. Even if the name does change and legal actions are taken to prevent us from using the name, the goal is still the same. The White/Orange/Blue designs uploaded on this page, including typography / typeface design, are property of 901 Customs Branding and The Label Lust Brand & Artist Management. Naming rights are not available for the complex facility itself, but high-traffic rooms within the facility unrelated to the skatepark. Featured and affiliated partners do not enforce or sponsor this campaign. Photos of skateparks and architecture or some perk product photos were provided to us by our followers on social media and google search, or digitally designed by 901 Customs, but are only used to represent the quality of the fully-developed final product, minimalist architectural taste, scale and fashion.

The original Skatepark of Memphis and associated photos;
(we do not own these images nor did we own this park) The New Skatepark of Memphis is an idea which could potentially take the original park's place. Names, Branding images, product designs, marketing and promotional materials are subject to change.

Please do not submit any unsolicited ideas, original creative artwork, suggestions or other works (“submissions”) in any form to 901 Customs or The Label Lust or any of its employees unless otherwise stated in a perk. The sole purpose of this policy is to avoid potential misunderstandings or disputes when 901 Customs or The Label Lust’s ideas, products or marketing strategies might seem similar to ideas submitted to 901 Customs or The Label Lust. If, despite our request that you not send us your ideas (unless otherwise stated in a or somewhere on our a particular area of our website), you still submit them, then regardless of what your letter says, the following terms shall apply to your submissions.

Thanks for being part of one of our biggest projects!This campaign is sponsored and organized by



EASY NAVIGATION

What We're Doing / Why / Community Benefits / Risks & Challenges

Featured Brands & Affiliated Partners / Disclaimer / Terms of Idea Submission
People Are Talking



What We're Doing
(Where your money and our money is going)
A Brand New Entertainment and Personal Development Facility(Part 1 of our campaign is to fund the development of an indoor skatepark)
*Please note: We aren't 'Re-building' the Skatepark of Memphis that once existed.This is an entirely new project and we've been granted permission from previous owners to use the original name. Skatepark of Memphis was built with years of hard work, dedication and community support. We do not wish to discredit the family that spent their time and money to birth such a great experience for the Memphis alternative sports community, Memphis' independent music scene and the youth who contributed to the success of the park and it's name. We have a unique opportunity to make Memphis a part of the, now, mainstream sport.
The provision of a sport or recreation facility can significantly 
enhance the quality of life. Activities held within sport and recreation
 facilities can encourage participation, promote health and well-being 
and foster a sense of community. However, planning a sport or recreation
 facility is an involved and sometimes difficult task. Our project is big. OUR PROJECT IS HUGE and
 considering that this is an individual effort to support independent 
artists, designers, business owners, brands and, in general, creatives, 
The project may or may not be partially funded by the city/state 
and could take 1-3 years to be fully funded before construction begins. 
The park will be designed and constructed by California Skateparks.The photos below are rendered to represent quality and do NOT accurately represent architecture, park design, material use or scale.




In addition, our goal is to open a skate-bike-inline shop (featuring 
products from both local and well known brands) and a flagship popup 
shop featuring only products from sponsored artists, affiliate partners
& Memphis-based Indie apparel brands The Label Lust Apparel + Affiliated Partners like ME Skateboarding Co.The photos below are rendered to represent quality and minimalist taste but do NOT accurately represent architecture, shop design, material use or scale.


The Skatepark of Memphis will be a privately owned park. In an effort
 to support local independent talent, local small and big independently 
owned businesses, provide job and internship opportunities, education, 
relationship and wealth building strategies to the Memphis community, 
the Indoor skatepark and surrounding facilities (eg. apparel design, 
recording, photography, videography, visual art, technology, dance, 
business network and digital branding studios) will be accessible via 
monthly/annual memberships or pay-per-day and pay-per-session rates. 
This would allow us to keep the park open forever and could allow us to 
keep the lights on 24/7. The facility will be constructed with 
state-of-the art materials and technology and the park itself would be 
constructed with concrete, minimizing hazards and upkeep costs. 


Back to top.

 
A Professionally Designed Concrete Skatepark Will: • Provide a safe challenging place for skateboarding (and similar extreme sports), allowing participants to develop as athletes•
 Provide an alternative to team sports, to develop motor skills & 
balance in youth and the young-at-heart. Playgrounds are provided for 
younger children, but for older youth who don’t participate in team 
sports, there is often nothing.• Attract visitors (skatepark 
enthusiasts & spectators) who enjoy skateboarding & similar 
extreme sports. When people visit they spend money!• Make community 
more youth-friendly & give youth the message that they’re accepted 
& valued members of the community, by giving them a place to call 
their own & a creative outlet to express themselves• Provide 
opportunity for healthy activity for youth, helping curb problems of 
inactivity & drug abuse (According to local Addiction Services, the 
most common reason given by youth for drug abuse is boredom.)• 
Provide opportunities to host events, shows & jams (competitions), 
presenting skating in a format that people can understand & 
appreciate. Skateboarding is a great spectator sport!• Provide 
opportunities for “hard to reach, non-joining youth” to get involved in 
the community & foster creativity as each skater develops his own 
personal style and skills
According to veteran skateboarder Dan 
Hughes, “Skateboarding reaches these “at risk” youth, like no other 
sport. And it’s cool too. But, people are out of touch with what is 
happening, and just want to get these annoying skateboarders out of 
their hair. All the while, kids are learning that as skaters they are 
second-class citizens. Yet, it’s these same skateboarders who are 
learning a valuable work ethic. Because, believe me, if you don’t work 
hard and commit to a trick, you won’t land it. They also learn how to 
work independently, how to be creative, and develop their own 
style.”
• Provide social opportunities by bringing different ages and social 
groups together, encouraging interaction and appreciation of each other;
 bring families together who enjoy skating as a family• Empower 
youth by involving them fully in the process of establishing the park, 
enabling them to work with community elders, learning how government 
works & how they can become more active citizens• Encourage 
youth to interact independently & develop socially, learning how to 
take turns & help each other learn new tricks• Mitigate street 
skating problems, protecting private & public property from damage 
& reducing police time required to follow up on complaints. For 
example, 75% of 24 communities surveyed by the City of Calgary in 1998, 
after their skatepark opened, reported a significant reduction in the 
skate problem.• Reduce pressure on hospitals as a result of reduced 
injuries from skating on rough surfaces and in traffic areas, i.e. 
street-skating. (According to Health Canada, only 5% of skateboarding 
injuries take place in skateparks.)• Provide a healthy release for pent-up aggression & frustration•
 Teach the importance of a positive attitude & belief in oneself. To
 progress in skateboarding, one must trust oneself & believe that 
they can do it!• Provide economic benefits.
“Community Access to a variety of 
recreational opportunities encourages business investment from outside 
the community, acts as a driver for immigration, and encourages resident
 retention (particularly among youth). Destination marketing and tourism
 development are closely tied with the number and quality of recreation 
activities developed and available.”
A skatepark would fit well into Memphis Grizzlies' established slogan “Grit n Grind”-Grit defining Courage and Resolve; Strength of Character-Grind defining Work-ethic and Persistence; Mental and Physical Dedication to setting and completing Goals and literally grinding (obviously) 
Skateboarding is HUGE, just not hugely supported in Memphis.
Thanks to Jim Barnum of Spectrum Skateparks and California Skateparks for many of the above ideas.

photo source: dewtour.com
Back to top.


How will this benefit the Memphis Youth?
The myth surrounding skateparks is that they are a breeding ground 
for crime and other illicit activities. While there will be an 
occasional "bad seed", providing designated spaces for positive 
activities is the best way to curb unlawful behavior among youth. When 
the youth has nothing to do or nowhere to go - that is when they are 
more likely to cause trouble and risk not only other people's lives, but
 their own.It's no secret that children who are involved in team
 sports don't have the time to get into trouble, but it turns out you 
don't have to drag them to the soccer field or baseball diamond. 
Activities you may not expect - like skateboarding - might be just what 
teens and adolescents need. Research out of the University of North 
Carolina found that skateboarding is among the activities that might 
help keep children out of trouble. Many adults who aren't involved in 
the skateboarding community see the group of boarders as being a little 
more on the risky side, but instead of being on the risky side, they are
 actually protected from those behaviors.Source: NBC Philadelphia"Keeping Active is the Best way to keep kids out of trouble" April 3, 2006By
 all means, skateboarding can be a dangerous sport. It's indubitably 
dangerous when skating in the streets due to a lack in public skating 
parks, but what I believe is more dangerous than that are public parks 
that are open 24/7 with no lighting, weatherproofing, enforced 
regulations or supervision.An indoor, well-maintained, 
well-supervised, well-lit, well-ventilated and regulated skating 
facility would revoke illegal activity, destruction of public & 
private property, violence, and unethical influence and allow skaters an
 opportunity to leave their homes and be active on days of bad weather; 
the healthy alternative to playing video games and watching Netflix.One
 of the psycho-social benefits is to feel safe again. Reclaiming public 
spaces helps people feel like a community and the busier the place, the 
more appealing for the youth and the safer people feel.The 
majority of skateboarding injuries happen outside of skateparks. The 
most common injuries are falls due to surface irregularities and 
collisions with motor vehicles or pedestrians. Skateboarding is going to
 happen whether skateparks exist or not, so the best way to keep youth 
safe is to provide to them access to positively influenced, safe, 
designated spaces to pursue their activity.

Back to top.

In Association with Skatepark of Memphis 




AWARE TO CARE Greater Memphis Area Protection Program(To donate protective recreation gear)SPOM SHOP's Game of S.K.E.I.G.H.T Live Broadcast 2017 in Memphis TN(Competitive event to increase community and Corporate involvement)Skatepark of Memphis Aggressive Inline, & BMX Skateshop Best Trick 2017(Competitive event to increase community and Corporate involvement)SPOM's Skateboarding for Purpose in Memphis Board Donor(To donate complete skateboards to kids and young adults)(designs and names subject to change)


Risks & Challenges

There is not a single parks manager who doesn’t see a way to improve 
any  recreational facility. The challenges facing parks are everywhere; 
the expensive  maintenance costs of a new soccer field, finding 
qualified volunteers for an after-school program, or the lack of  land 
for an off-leash dog park. The  fact is that no recreational facility is
 without its particular needs  and no project is perfect in every way.
Skateparks
 are a relative newcomer to the Parks & Recreation world  and it can
 be difficult to sort out all of the voices with something to  say. 
Attorneys deliver a list of policies and devices necessary  to mitigate 
liability. Planners have a short list of available sites  appropriate 
for this kind of development (if at all). Meanwhile, the  neighborhood 
delivers its own list of concerns about noise and nuisance. While this 
is all getting sorted out the skateboarders are recreating in the 
streets. The  business community is fed up with their ledges being 
ground down to  nothing and the police are writing tickets to skaters 
when they have better things to do. Everyone wants the new skatepark but
 few people can agree on what and where it should be, work together to volunteer or find the money to donate. This is where 
skateparks begin to fail.
We’re all familiar with the difficult 
environment in which skateparks  are expected to become successes. It 
should come as no surprise that  sometimes they fail to meet everyone’s 
expectations.  Hope is not lost! There are still options even when it 
feels like every  avenue has been explored.Our biggest expenses will probably be RENT and INSURANCE.
 While providing services and products would be a great way to 
financially support brands & businesses and the communities that 
support those brands & businesses, we do not expect to cover insurance, rent, utility, employment, management and upkeep fees 
associated with owning a skatepark from these outlets alone (meaning we have other plans in place to generate income within and outside of the new facility).We hope to find a SPACE large enough to include a parking lot for plenty of parking space - an indoor park large enough to allow simultaneous use by boarders, inline skaters and bikers safely - and a building large enough to include multiple rooms for retail, creative opportunities for partners/customers/clients/members, the park (of course), shows (that don't interrupt park activity) and large events (like televised board/bike/skate competitions, club parties and fashion shows  -  things that would increase community involvement, consumer spending & drive INCOME to help fund park maintenance, employment, product design & manufacturing, advertising, sponsorships and overheads.While searching for a place to call home, we have to consider thing like LICENSING, ZONING CLEARANCE and PERMITS (for clubbing, indoor parks, commerce, broadcasting, etc)Building a concrete park will be EXPENSIVE. The advantage is that maintenance costs will decrease drastically. Buying (not renting) a building will be VERY EXPENSIVE. The advantage, though, is that we (park users) can make the rules and make any decisions necessary for the satisfaction and safety of our community.DESIGN is commonly an issue. Fortunately, California Skateparks has one of the best reputations in skatepark-building history. Unfortunately, they're not architects. We're still searching for the right architect for the job.TIME is a major concern. Will the park open this year? Lets be realistic - probably not, considering the goals we've set and are determined to achieve.SUPPORT - Under-funding a facility that is expected to meet the needs for the entire local community AND attract visitors. Skateboarders aren't millionaires. Not even some of the best professionals. Mid-level skaters earn $50 to $100K a year, while the really good guys make between $500K and $1 million. But how much of that do they have to fund a park? How much of that do they actually keep?
 But believe it or not, it's rarely about the money. Basically skaters 
get paid to do what they would be doing anyway, which is trying to skate
 better than the laws of physics allow." Most amateur skaters don't have enough money in their pockets to replace the skateboard they just broke and if they do, they've usually already got in mind where they're going to spend it and what they're going to buy. Our funding is likely to come from investors, parents, sponsors and ourselves (with pleasure). LOW CAPACITY - Underestimating the value of (and not planning for) the skatepark as a social space to the local youth. Seating and other aspects of design that make the space comfortable and inviting are very important to the long-term health of the park. If the facility is designed to handle this social function it will be that much better off. When the popularity of the new skatepark is underestimated, particularly when site amenities and the surroundings are not designed to be social spaces, behavior at the park can become unruly. OPPORTUNITY - Embarking upon the process of creating a new skatepark is a great opportunity to embrace a popular and fascinating youth activity. The new park should be seen as a boon to the community that will be VERY popular with the youth. With proper planning and good decisions, the skatepark will be a landmark for the entire community. This is a rare and exciting opportunity.

We have three two options:
1.) Find a location and building (usually a warehouse space) 
big enough to include a spacious parking lot, seating (for shows, 
competitions and jams) and floor space (for broadcasters and film gear 
during events), and a skatepark big enough to include efficient design 
for: sectioning (to give bikers, boarders and inline skaters access to a
 particular section during a 30 minute session if needed), skill level 
(to give young children or beginners a safe section to practice and 
progress) and ride-ability (to ensure the entire park can be utilized 
and enjoyed at it's utmost potential for each rider's style and 
preference).
2.) Find an empty lot for reasons mentioned above and build a 
brand new facility. (preferred over renovating or experiencing design 
limitations with existing lots)
(We think we've found the perfect spot downtown near the Pyramid 
where we can drive visitor traffic and increase sales for nearby 
businesses, but we're still doing research on zoning and permits. If 
you've got information that may beneficial to us, please email support@theskateparkofmemphis.com)

3.) Build a free, outdoor skatepark Memphis 
already has a few of these and they are GREAT! If we decided to raise 
money to build a free outdoor park we, instead, would invest that money 
into improving the existing parks to make them safer, more enjoyable, 
well lit and more complete. For example: -We would add a pool (or pools, 
and we don't mean a swimming pool), dedicated lighting and more seating 
with outdoor heaters to the Houston High park

- Expand and add concrete 
sections and lighting to Southaven Skate Park- Add lighting to Tobey 
park- And of course we'd do whatever we can for the DIY guys over at 
ALTOWN.Often,
 Memphis' ridiculous weather and lack of necessary resources and space 
make it hard for kids, young adults and long-time riders to fully enjoy 
skateboarding outdoors. We don't want to discourage support for local 
parks, instead we'd love to give Memphis skaters, bikers and visitors 
from all over the world the opportunity to enjoy a full day's worth of 
skateboarding and have access to a clean, ventilated and safe 
community-driven environment. These existing parks are VERY important to
 the Memphis skateboarding 
community and if when the opportunities unfold, our investments into these parks and their supporting communities are guaranteed.
Back to top.

Memphis' support system for independent talents, small businesses, relationships, self-improvement, success, the youth....(I could go on and on)... has kind-of gone to shit. Our community doesn't really feel inspired to do anything unless they know they'll see results tomorrow - unless they know it's going to benefit them in some kind of way - unless it tears down their competition. See, I'm not about competition, or tearing people down. I'm not about doing everything for the benefit of myself and having that 9-5 job barely making enough to feed my snake (who only needs to eat once a month) and skating at free parks or in the cove every time I want to get on a board, because every time I've I wanted to go out and get on board, the weather said NO. The neighbors complained. The park was dirty. No one being at the public park and the sun nearly generating a cup-full of sweat and the built-up dirt at the bottom of the banks -- weren't worth my almost empty tank of gas. Any request to change or fix an issue at a public park (cracks or a broken rail) or add, lets say, a bowl to the Houston High park is either denied or takes 15 years to finally be fulfilled. If we owned that park it would have been done either by us or with volunteer help of the people who truly wanted it. But because we don't own that park, we have to ask non-skateboarding politicians to do something that would benefit us, but they would have to pay for.

Q: Why is there so much to read?
A: Well, because there's so much to do and we don't have a campaign video (yet)We're waiting on video submissions from Memphis skaters to land in our inbox and those (usually) take a while to make. The organizers (myself and one other) are pretty busy researching, networking and spending hard-earned money trying to make this thing happen for you. You wouldn't have come this far down the page if you weren't remotely interested. Besides, reading is good practice for the mind and I encourage you to do so more often. A book I recommend reading is Mental Dynamics by K. Thomas Finley.

claimed the "You've Got Mail" perk, you'll be the first to know when we 
find a location - assuming that your address hasn't changed between now 
and then, you'll receive exclusive 'GRIT & GRIND SPOM' stickers in 
the mail.

of your contribution is not the same thing as buying something online. 
Perks may require much more than just money to develop, manufacture and 
distribute.

 exciting to hear that you've found multiple perks you are interested in

to be able to add multiple perks in a single transaction. As such, if 
you'd like to claim multiple perks, please make a new contribution for 
each perk.(Read More about perks here)

Back to top.


About Us

The  is an affiliate of The Label Lust Brand & Artist Management Agency. We,  are a conglomerate of independent brands which provide 6 service groups to our creative clients and affiliated partner brands:






along with endorsements and sponsorships, essentially eliminating the middle-men and providing countless opportunities for the Memphis community. Our goal as an Agency is to provide to our clients and partners a one-stop-shop of the necessary education, resources and services to enhance their entrepreneur careers and expedite their journey to success.
We hope to redefine what it means to be an independent creative and teach young professionals how to network, collaborate, better understand business, finance and relationship building, and not necessarily what, but where & how to think more efficiently in our more connected, modern world.


Many
“Entertainment” companies are more-so interested in making a dollar than
providing their clients with the opportunity to do the same. We do not solely
consider our customers “Clients”, but instead, Partners. That is what sets
our agency apart from our competition. Entering a joint agreement as individual
businesses & brands with a common goal to generate residual revenue
and marketing exposure for both, or all parties involved, ultimately building wealthier relationships and solid foundations of trust and transparency, all while increasing independent community interest and involvement. 
Back to top.

story:
After many years servicing my community and surrounding communities, saving, educating, obtaining a Builder's license and starting a residential construction company nine years ago. I built this beautiful 3,888 sq. ft., spec home in 2009 (shown as this campaign's image), hoping for a quick sell to help finance my Disaster Ready Homes project. It haven’t been sold yet.

    My project dream consist of building and making available to the public my own designs of "Disaster Ready Homes"

 

    These homes will look normal at surface level but will incorporate comfortable underground living spaces with the normal living amenities (including parking) and smart home technology. If you're building a new home from blueprints, even the simplest and smallest of home plans can be (custom) converted into a "Disaster Ready Home" with some redesign skills or know-how (to meet local code) during the planning stage (before construction begin). The purpose is to provide safe familiar shelter with enough space for the family, also for friends and neighbors if they aren't prepared for severe weather conditions. Your valuable  outdoor property like cars, small boats, equipment,.. etc., can also be sheltered. When unwelcome disasters strike, you'll be prepared better than most, and my designs can be EMP ready, if desired. (Visit this campaign's "Gallery" for more animations).

    My campaign goal is to sell this last remaining spec home to pay off construction loans

.

 Any remaining funds and funds raised in this campaign will finance my "Disaster Ready Homes" project. This project will create jobs and possibly start a new housing market niche for my company going forward. It may also set a new standard for the housing industry. Once this home is built it will be used partly as a model and live-in for study. 

.

    Your donation to this fundraising campaign of any amount is greatly appreciated and please share this campaign with your network. To show my gratitude for your support & donations I'm offering "Perks", I will reduce my contracting service fee by 10% and 05% on new home construction and 05% for "other home services" listed on my website, whether or not I reach this campaign goal.

This campaign's (image) home for sell is currently leased and will be lease free and back on the market by July 15, 2015. If you’re considering purchasing a beautiful home or investment property located in Durham, near the Research Triangle Park area of North Carolina, please consider purchasing this home. This home is conveniently located near the major Universities, Duke University, UNC of Chapel Hill, North Carolina State University as well as near a host of popular shopping centers.

To honor perks, your new home has to be built near the Durham, North Carolina and Research Triangle park area. To claim your Perk/s (when ready), visit www.homegemsinc.com, use the big "form" button on the "Contact & Project Submittal" page to submit your claim and start the process. To get more info on this campaign's home for sell, email me at rmastertrim@homegemsinc.com.  For more info of my "Disaster Ready Homes" design project, visit www.homegemsinc.com on the home page, read the “Ultimate Cad Home Design Possibilities” and click on the “3D Cad Simulation” button at the bottom. This will show and describe how a simple home (from blueprints) can go through a conversion and or expansion and become a custom home to meet your needs. Email me at rmastertrim@homegemsinc.com for your project conversion.

Thanks for considering my campaign. Your support, contributions and efforts of sharing this campaign with your social network/s, groups and email contacts (personal or business) will surely get me across the goal line. Thank you.

story:
Hello! Welcome coffee-lovers and all!

My name is Bailey and I'm going to tell you a little story. Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Kelly. One day, Kelly was driving with her father, Joe, and looked down, noticing that the floorboards were littered with coffee cups. Perplexed, she asked, "Dad, why do you drink coffee in the summer?" He smiled and questioned back, "Why do you eat ice cream in the winter?" She made the connection and nodded her head, continuing on her day.

On multiple other occasions, Kelly was either sent into the convenience store to make his coffee or she made it at home. You would think that a girl would hate to have an extra chore, but that is not the way she looked at it. One day after she got her father's coffee, he smiled and told her that she makes the best coffee in the world, even better than her sisters, which she appreciated a lot, being the youngest of the three. 

It wasn't until the fateful day in 1992 when Kelly's world would change forever. Round Valley Reservoir in Lebanon, NJ. Scuba Diving Accident. Air Embolism to the brain. Kelly was 12 years-old, swarmed with heartache, along with her two sisters Jodi and Stacy, and their mother, Donna. 

Kelly is my mother. Again, my name is Bailey. So let's lighten the air a bit. I'm Kelly's daughter and I currently am employed at Java Joe's, a cozy, little coffee shop in Beachwood, NJ that my mom decided to open up to carry on my grandfather's legacy. After all, the famous Java Joe said it himself, my mom makes the best coffee in the world, so I'd say that was a smart move on her part. 

Small businesses and mom&pop shops are rapidly becoming a "forgotten art" if you will, becoming swallowed up by the endless chains of commercial retailers and restaurants. Our little shop is getting such good reviews and publicity, but good words can only take us so far. I want to surprise my mom with any amount of money that could potentially improve the financial situation we're in now. She wants to make improvements. She wants to advertise. Quality is a top priority. In order to do enhance our family business, I was hoping to gain the help of my community and anyone around the country who is willing enough to help out my mom and to keep the dreams of honoring her father alive. 

A VERY IMPORTANT REQUEST

This is a surprise for my mother. I don't want to spoil the surprise until everything is finalized. Feel free to like Java Joe's on Facebook, but try and refrain from tagging us in anything that has to do with this fundraiser. If you stop into the shop, please don't say anything to my mom. Thank you all!

The Funds We Get

Ultimately, the funds will go to the shop in general, and serve to make various improvements around the shop. More glasses, a better security system, or anything that helps the shop run smoother for not only the staff, but the customers as well. Advertising is going to be a key component to the continuing success of our business. With this money, we'll be able to advertise and catch people's eye, and make the money that the shop deserves. 

What Your Dollar Will Do:

  • Support a local coffee shop in a world of commercial retailers. 
  • Help a woman's dream of honoring her father.
  • Improve the shop and the anxiety levels of my mom. 
  • Provide a unique experience for our customers.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! 

We're on Facebook! Like us!

Come visit us!

We show local artists!

Tell us your story!

story:
Who are we

My name is Linda Nebēdniece. I am a musician, raw foodist and mother of two daughters. There is a scenic place in Latvia called Pērļukrāces where I assemble people who are interested in ecological, healthy and alternative way of living. My biggest dream is to create a place and community where people can feel them selves free, self sustainable, natural and positive. All of this is happening already at my house: we are building with natural materials such as clay and straw, growing ecological produce without pesticides, we are cooking vegetarian meals, singing powerful songs, dancing Latvian traditional dances, making our psalteries (or kokle in Latvian), celebrating solstice, organizing camps and other activities.

For me and my friends this is not a experiment, we really do live like this. Latvian traditional way of life is something deep-minded and beautiful, it's like a part of us, inside our cells. I can't imagine a day without playing psaltery, lighting a wood-burning stove, walking bare foot, meditating in a meadow..

Why we need your help 

This place Pērļukrāces has became dear to my family and friends, visitors. It's our third year living here and during this time with the help of our friends we have made this place much more beautiful and comfortable for living. All of this time owners of this house allowed us to live here without charge, but now they want to sell this place. We are privileged to be the first ones to make an offer and buy this place. We don't have a lot of time, because our neighbor is interested in buying the land and forest around the house. The neighbor is wealthy and willing to buy, but we are limited in money. If he buys this place, he will grow grains using chemical fertilizers and that will pollute the river which runs by the property. He will most certainly cut the forest. Even if the house still stays as ours, this beautiful place will loose it's charm. For the community this has been a place free of stress, communications and commerce, but now all of this is endangered.

Why exactly this place?

It' s not easy to explain, but everyone who comes here, starts to understand why. A lot of people have said they feel high vibrations in these surroundings, especially in Druviena, Silmači. Poruka museum, Dievlejas, Ielejas, Kļaviņi and other local places. People who live here have always loved the earth, water, sun, traditional songs and music instruments, wood-crafting, connection with the cycles of nature.

My vision

I'm sure that with time this place will grow even more. as a location for spiritual and healthy living people. At this moment it's a special place in Latvia, but in near future it might became known outside the borders of this country. A lot of people have showed their interest to come visit and take part in things that happen here.

There is a plan to continue organizing raw-food camps and master classes in Pērļukrāces. celebrating traditional festivals, creating activities in permaculture, music, yoga, poetry, development of children etc. We plan to create a alternative school, where children will learn meaningful knowledge throughout the practical experience and nature.

This place gives an opportunity to go swimming naked in the river, meditate in a scenic meadow, take a walk in forest, taking natural beauty care of oils, blue clay, dry brushing and many more. Everyone can paint, dance, sing, create.. You can always feast on tasty and fresh food together with musicians, artists, philosophers, travelers and feel connected with nature, the Universe and love yourself and everything around you.

What we need...

At this point we have 5000 euros. In order to buy the house, forest (4 hectares) and the land (6 hectares) we need 20 000 euros.

I believe that if we do something good to others then the Universe, God or however you want to call it, pays back in a more bigger amounts through different situations and people. It's a kind of a unwritten law that works!

Dear friend, if you can support us even just with the smallest amount of money, it will came back to you, because of your generous heart. You will always be a welcomed visitor in Pērļukrāces.

Gifts to our supporters

We want to thank our supporters with inspiring printable posters 25 and post cards 100. We understand that these gifts are small, but that's all that we have. Maybe these postcards and posters will bring more joy to your life and help you became more happy.

If we won't collect the necessary amount of money..

..In that case I will be forced to seek for creditors. That might be a hard time for my family and a lot of hard work. My youngest daughter is only 9 months old. I want to be able to spend time with my children and create what I' m most passionate about – community in which everyone can reconnect with nature, themselves and the purpose of life. In Latvia we have quite small salaries and aliments.

You can also help in other ways. 

If you can' t help with money you can share this information with others that might be able to help. It also might inspire someone to join us and change their way of life! Thank you for your time!

Ommm...

which everyone can reconnect with nature, themselves and the purpose
of life. In Latvia we have quite small salaries and aliments.
You
can also help in other ways. 

If you can' t help
with money you can share this information with others that might be
able to help. It also might inspire someone to join us and change
their way of life! Thank you for your time! 


Ommm...

story:
Help Us Get Cooking!

We’ve got the vision; we’ve got the space, now we need you to bring the heat! $10,000 will cover the cost of the essential kitchen equipment for Hands On Hartford’s new community center.

Why is this so Important?

Just like where you live, this kitchen will be the heart of our new home. This kitchen will have many purposes: providing training, feeding people in need, creating jobs for those who are unemployed.


What We Need 

Your gift will help to provide the essential industrial appliances to cook meals for those in need. This includes: an oven, range, griddle, charbroiler. This kitchen will be built to last and help our Hartford neighbors for years to come!


The Impact

You can help people like David (in the video above) with valuable opportunities for training, employment, volunteering, nutritious meals, and connections with other community members.

Hands On Hartford currently serves over 5,000 people in need every year. Think of how many of those lives could benefit from a kitchen like this. Think about how many more people we will be helping in our new community center! As David said, it’s going to feed a lot of mouths, and as Barbara said, provide a lot of jobs!


Other Ways You Can Help

Share this page with everyone you know! Talk about it at parties, tweet it at celebrities, shout it from the rooftops! Join us: be a part of the team in getting the word out!

story:
Healthy Habitats is a short term home where young men can continue to heal from addiction in a safe, sober, regimented and healthy environment.


MY STORY

Seven and a half years ago I started hiring young men in recovery to work with me in my residential gardening company. I worked along side them day in and day out and saw their struggles. 

Unfortunately, two of these young men have lost their lives to drug addiction. 

There is such a desperate need now for help for these young people. I am looking forward to opening a recovery house that is regimented with support; a healthy, sober and healing environment where they can start on their path to a clean and sober life.


WHERE WILL MY DONATION GO?

50,000 toward the purchase of a house

15,000 toward home improvements

10,000 toward furniture

5,000 toward legal fees and insurance


With your generous donations, I will be able to offer a supportive environment for young people in recovery. 


Please Donate and share this campaign with your friends and family!

story:
Ryan Lucks and John Thomas met three years ago at a neighborhood pool party and became friends over a mutual love of BBQ.  Two years later they decided to sign up for the DC BBQ Battle.  Their first competition was a learning experience, but both walked away with a growing interest in competitions.  They decided in 2015 they would compete in multiple events in an attempt to make the best BBQ around.


Big Boyz BBQ needs $750 for competition entry fees, supplies for the competitions and misc. expenses.  Our goal is to sign up for three competitions this summer.  We are planning on competing in the Fredericksburg (VA) BBQ Jamboree, the Beltway BBQ Showdown in Fort Washington, MD and the DC BBQ Battle in Washington, DC.
We are competing against professional grill masters with major sponsorship.  Big Boyz BBQ needs your help to show that 2 guys and a love of BBQ can compete.  All funds will be used for competitions.  If we do not raise enough funds - we will pay remaining balances ourselves - so rest assured any money that is donated will be used to create awesome BBQ.    
For those that help out our campaign - we will have some fun perks.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a contributions, you can assist Big Boyz BBQ in other ways.  Spread the word about our campaign.  Follow us on twitter and facebook (bigboyzbbq).  If you are in Northern Virginia - come to one of our neighborhood BBQ fundraisers.  Everyone can help Big Boyz BBQ make great ribs, brisket and pulled pork.

story:
Your number one source for in-home child care referral services. SeekingSitters local owners are working for you to help with your one-time, full-time, part-time or even last minute babysitting needs. Every sitter referred through SeekingSitters has undergone a thorough background screening so you know that only the most reliable and trustworthy sitters are sent to your home.  And all you have to do is log onto your online account and request a sitter for the day and time of your need and SeekingSitters handles the rest!

SeekingSitters Babysitter Referral Service is Reliable, Convenient, and Trustworthy. SeekingSitters families can Rely on their local owner to work for them and find a sitter for each specific need. One call to SeekingSitters or simply request online and an available prescreened Certified Sitter contacts you. SeekingSitters service provides Convenience to busy families by offering online services for scheduling, invoice tracking and sitter profile review. Your local SeekingSitters office is even available around the clock for your last minute needs.

My name is Natanya Bertin, and I am partnering with SeekingSitters to provide reliable, trustworthy and convenient babysitting services to families, with the best screening process in the industry.  SeekingSitters’ founder is a licensed private investigator and has organized an in-house investigative agency that provides a hands-on screening approach for all sitters and member families that utilize the service.  This ensures a safe, enjoyable experience for both the families and the Certified Professional Sitters. 

All funds raised through this Indiegogo campaign will go directly into launchingthisfranchisefor both the professional sitters and families. We will use the funds to payfranchisefees,operatingcost, marketingmaterials, andallothercost.

How You Can Get Involved

Every dollar we raise from this Indiegogo campaign will go into getting the SeekingSitters franchiseup and running, so we can open our doors early next year and begin referringsafeprofessional sitters.  We are asking for enough money to cover the very basic necessities of our franchise, and to help trainandhiresafeprofessional sitters.  Below is a rough overview how this funding will be allocated:

Franchise Fee - $40,000

Marketing- $8,000

Fees-$2,000

Please take a look at our perks to the right! If you donate the right amount, you can score a t-shirt, a book, or free babysitting. Please share on Facebook, Twitter, and other social media platforms.

story:
This fundraiser is in honour of my dear friend Thai Pham who sadly passed away in a freak accident earlier this year, on the 5th of August whilst on holiday with his family.
Thai was ever so devoted to his family, and was one of the most loyal friends I could have ever asked for. Coming a close second to his family, Thai loved football. He loved watching it, he loved the football video games and more importantly he loved to play football.
Every time a term ended at school and even at university, he would always meet up with his friends from his secondary school to play football, to make sure none of us ever strayed too far from him. He kept us together.
ALL the money from this fundraiser will go towards a memorial bench to be put up at the pitch where we always played, in memory of our beloved Thaiger so that people who play there in future will always remember him and what he loved.

story:
We want to create a space unlike any other that we have found. A place where people from the vaping community and gamers can come to purchase supplies, swap stories and create new tales that start out, "Remember that time at D20 ..."

So who is this we?

Our party is made up of a valiant businesswoman, Trisha Peters. Our fearless leader has high ranks in a variety of merchant skills. She is assisted by a tech wizard Alicia Secord, an artificer Rob Lifton, and a trusted apprentice Alyssa Long. This core party is just a small part of this adventure. Our future customers and friends are vital to reaching our goal. And the rewards will be plentiful.

We know that vape shops are popping up all over, but we will be more than just another shop. We will create a unique environment in which vape enthusiasts can purchase supplies, try a new juice, and pitch new ideas that we are willing to help bring to fruition. We will have pens, mechs, and an assortment of juices to appeal to the first time vaper or someone that is sure that they've tried it all. 

Although our concentration is going to be on the vape side of things, we are also passionate about gaming. As long time gamers, we want to be your place to try out new games (rpg or other tabletop). We want to bring new, interesting games to your table. We will carry the favorites, but we want to encourage creators to bring new games to life.

We want to be your store. We want your investment as a community, not just your money (although we'll take that, too). Which is why we decided to turn to IndieGoGo.

There's a thing that happens when people come together to share something: A community arises and connections are made. While gaming practically demands a group of 2 or more people to function, vaping can -- in theory -- occur in a vacuum. But let's be honest, when you started vaping it likely was because someone took you to a vape shop.

So, when we started thinking, "Let's open a vape shop," the gaming side of things coalesced quickly, as well, because the only thing we like more than sitting around doing one of those things for hours is sitting around doing both of those things for hours. And when we started exploring funding options, we started finding tons of board and card games and even vaporizer mods that we wanted to order from Kickstarter and Indigogo. And we realized that this was the community we wanted to be a part of. Yes, we need additional start-up funding, but we want it to come in a way that allows us to pay forward rather than back.

We plan -- over the course of our business -- to support Kickstarter and Indigogo campaigns for start-up vaping and gaming suppliers. Our goal, over a few years, is to pay forward the amount that we raise in our Indigogo campaign to new developers. With the support of our customers, we can bring interesting, new products into the store that they won't find anywhere else and, in turn, support other small businesses and indie developers.


In order to make this happen we're aiming to raise $20,000. Here's where that money would be applied: Up front, we've got about 20% committed to: Indiegogo fees, Paypal and credit card fees, and to fulfill perks. That leaves us with about $16,000 for: 

  • $3000     First and last month rent 
  • $2700      Build out and permits 
  • $10,000  Inventory 
  • $300        Licensing fees 

To thank you for your contribution we offer: 

  • Vaping perks: Custom juices (all juice through this campaign will be 0-nic)
  • Gaming perks: Custom dice and bags
  • Multi-classing: Combination kits from both classes of perks
  • Plus some unique experiences at higher levels of giving

Click here for a further breakdown of the perks on our blog. You can help us make sure everyone gets their perks in as timely a manner as possible by providing us with your email and mailing address when you contribute to the campaign, so we don't have to track people down at the end. 


We've made assumptions. Yes we have. And assumptions point out risks and challenges in business. 

  • This is our first crowdfunding campaign, and our team's first venture together, but our team is made up of people with unique skills that are suited to bringing this project to fruition. Nevertheless, there may be ways we could run a project better that we haven't yet discovered.
  • Regulation of vaping and electronic cigarettes. On Aug. 8, the FDA closed public commenting on proposed regulations for e-cigarettes (and vaping). We acknowledge the FDA's concerns and are prepared to follow whatever regulatory requirements they deem necessary. It is our stance that we will not sell vaping products to minors. We also plan to obtain a tobacco license, as Michigan appears poised to require such licensing for vape shops.

If we don't hit our goal, other funding mechanisms will be sought and a number of things will happen:

  • Opening the store is delayed, but we will still open and we will fulfill our perks as quickly as possible. We won't lock in a location until the funding is in place, so the money won’t be lost … just redirected.
  • If we’re under our goal by a large amount we may have to simply fulfill perks and retool our idea. This doesn't mean we won't exist as a business, it means we will change our approach. A number of ideas have been explored for this contingency.

Tell EVERYONE about us!

  • Please like and share our Facebook page and follow us on Twitter!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share our campaign!

story:
A Medicine Garden for the People
In 2007 we started The Funny Farm, a suburban permaculture project on 3 acres outside Atlanta, GA. To further our work in caring for the Earth, caring for the people and providing a fair share for all, we are building a medicinal herb garden in our front yard. We want to promote herbal medicine and help our community learn how to grow their own medicines to support their own health and well-being.

The funds we raise will be used for:
  • purchasing plants
  • building arbors for climbing herbs
  • building a gathering space for classes and ceremonies.


This garden will provide many benefits to our community.

  • It will be a place to experiment with growing a wide variety of medicinal herbs
  • It will be a space where people can come to learn about the many benefits of herbal medicine
  • It will allow us to promote growing medicinal herbs as an additional source of income for local farmers
  • It will provide habitat for many different beings : birds, pollinators, bees, butterflies, frogs, toads, snakes and many more make their homes with us at the Funny Farm.

    In 2013 we launched Stone Mountain Herbs to supply our community through local farmers markets with herbal tea blends and other herbal remedies. This garden will allow us to reduce our footprint on the Earth by providing us with herbs for our medicines that we currently purchase from outside sources which get their herbs from all over the world.


The Grow an Herb Row Project

This year we have begun the Grow an Herb Row project to recruit local farmers and gardeners to grow medicinal herbs and donate them to  our partner, the Herbalista Free Clinic/Herb Bus. The Herbalista Free Clinic provides free herbal medical care to our local underserved community.

We will be converting our garage into a drying facility to process the herbs grown for the free clinic.

The funds we raise in this campaign will also be used to purchase the following:

  • seeds for our growing partners
  • replace the garage doors
  • build drying racks for drying herbs
  • purchase fans to circulate air
  • purchase containers for the dried herbs
  • build storage space for the dried herbs

Please support this important work to promote herbal medicine for the people.
